original: 2 Sabbaññubhāvapañha

translated: The Question about Omniscience

original: “Bhante nāgasena, buddho sabbaññū”ti?
analyzed: bhante nāgasena buddhaḥ sabbaññu iti
translated: “Is the Buddha omniscient, revered Nāgasena?”

original: “Āma, mahārāja, bhagavā sabbaññū, na ca bhagavato satataṁ samitaṁ ñāṇadassanaṁ paccupaṭṭhitaṁ, āvajjanapaṭibaddhaṁ bhagavato sabbaññutañāṇaṁ, āvajjitvā yadicchakaṁ jānātī”ti.
analyzed: āma mahā rāja bhagavā sabbaññū na ca bhagavato satatam samitam ñāṇa dassanam paccupaṭṭhite āvajjana paṭibaddham bhagavataḥ sabbaññu ta ñāṇe āvajjitvā yadicchakam jānāti iti
translated: “Yes, sire, the Blessed One is omniscient, but the knowledge and vision of the Blessed One is not constantly and continuously present before him. The omniscience of the Blessed One is bound up with his adverting. He knows whatever he wishes to know by adverting to it.”

original: “Tena hi, bhante nāgasena, buddho asabbaññūti.
analyzed: tena hi bhante nāgasena buddhaḥ a sabbaññu iti
translated: “Well then, revered Nāgasena, the Buddha is not omniscient.

original: Yadi tassa pariyesanāya sabbaññutañāṇaṁ hotī”ti.
analyzed: yadi tassa pariyesanāya sabbaññuta ñāṇam hoti iti
translated: If his omniscience comes about by seeking.”

original: “Vāhasataṁ kho, mahārāja, vīhīnaṁ aḍḍhacūḷañca vāhā vīhisattambaṇāni dve ca tumbā
analyzed: vāha satam kho mahā rāja vīhīnam aḍḍhacūḷam ca vāhāḥ vīhi sattambaṇāni dve ca tumbā
translated: “Sire, a hundred cartloads of paddy, and a hundred and fifty khārī of rice, and two tumbas of beans,

original: ekaccharākkhaṇe pavattacittassa ettakā vīhī lakkhaṁ ṭhapīyamānā parikkhayaṁ pariyādānaṁ gaccheyyuṁ?
analyzed: ekaccharā khaṇe pavatta cittassa ettakā vīhī lakkham ṭhapīyamānā parikkhayam pariyādānam gaccheyyu
translated: would that be enough to make a laksha of beans if they were counted by someone who had a thought-moment of seven days’ duration?”

original: Tatrime sattavidhā cittā pavattanti—
analyzed: tatra ime sattavidhā cittā pavattanti
translated: “Seven kinds of thought occur in him:

original: ye te, mahārāja, sarāgā sadosā samohā sakilesā abhāvitakāyā abhāvitasīlā abhāvitacittā abhāvitapaññā, tesaṁ taṁ cittaṁ garukaṁ uppajjati dandhaṁ pavattati.
analyzed: ye te mahā rāja sa rāgā sa dosā sa mohā sa kilesāḥ abhāvita kāyāḥ abhāvita sīlāḥ abhāvita cittāḥ abhāvita paññā tesam tam cittam garukam uppajjati dandham pavattati
translated: “Those, sire, who are full of passion, hatred and folly, who are defiled, whose body, virtue, mind and wisdom are undeveloped, their mind arises slowly and moves slowly.

original: Kiṁ kāraṇā?
analyzed: kim kāraṇā
translated: Why is that?

original: Abhāvitattā cittassa.
analyzed: a bhāvita ttā cittassa
translated: Because of the undeveloped state of the mind.

original: Yathā, mahārāja, vaṁsanāḷassa vitatassa visālassa vitthiṇṇassa saṁsibbitavisibbitassa sākhājaṭājaṭitassa ākaḍḍhiyantassa garukaṁ hoti āgamanaṁ dandhaṁ.
analyzed: yathā mahā rāja vasanāḷassa vitatassa visālassa vitthiṇṇassa sa sibbita visibbitassa sa ākhājaṭā jaṭitassa ākaḍḍhiyantassa garukam hoti āgamanam dandha
translated: As, sire, when a bamboo is long, wide, extensive, interlaced and entangled with branches and creepers, it is slow in coming and slow in moving.

original: Kiṁ kāraṇā?
analyzed: kim kāraṇā
translated: Why is that?

original: Saṁsibbitavisibbitattā sākhānaṁ.
analyzed: sa sibbita visibbita ttā
translated: Because of the interlaced and entangled state of the branches and creepers.

original: Evameva kho, mahārāja, ye te sarāgā sadosā samohā sakilesā abhāvitakāyā abhāvitasīlā abhāvitacittā abhāvitapaññā, tesaṁ taṁ cittaṁ garukaṁ uppajjati dandhaṁ pavattati.
analyzed: evam eva kho mahā rāja ye te sa rāgā sa dosā sa mohā sa kilesā abhāvita kāyā abhāvita sīlā abhāvita cittā abhāvita paññā tesam tam cittam garukam uppajjati dandham pavattati
translated: Even so, sire, those who are full of passion, hatred and folly, who are defiled, whose body, virtue, mind and wisdom are undeveloped, their mind arises slowly and moves slowly.

original: Kiṁ kāraṇā?
analyzed: kim kāraṇā
translated: Why is that?

original: Saṁsibbitavisibbitattā kilesehi, idaṁ paṭhamaṁ cittaṁ.
analyzed: sa sibbita visibbita ttā kilesehi idam paṭhamam citta
translated: Because of the interlaced and entangled state of the defilements. This is the first mind.

original: Tatridaṁ dutiyaṁ cittaṁ vibhattamāpajjati—
analyzed: tatra idam dutiyam cittam vibhattam āpajjati
translated: Herein, sire, the second mind is analysed thus—

original: ye te, mahārāja, sotāpannā pihitāpāyā diṭṭhippattā viññātasatthusāsanā, tesaṁ taṁ cittaṁ tīsu ṭhānesu lahukaṁ uppajjati lahukaṁ pavattati.
analyzed: ye te mahā rāja sotāpannāḥ pihita apāyāḥ diṭṭhi ppattāḥ viññāta satthu sāsanā tesam tam cittam tīsu ṭhānesu lahukam uppajjati lahukam pavattati
translated: “Your Majesty, the minds of those stream-enterers who have closed off the lower realms, who have attained the view, who have understood the Teacher’s message, arise and occur lightly in three cases.

original: Uparibhūmīsu garukaṁ uppajjati dandhaṁ pavattati.
analyzed: upari bhūmīsu garukam uppajjati dandham pavattati
translated: In the higher stages they arise and occur heavily.

original: Kiṁ kāraṇā?
analyzed: kim kāraṇā
translated: Why is that?

original: Tīsu ṭhānesu cittassa parisuddhattā upari kilesānaṁ appahīnattā.
analyzed: tīsu ṭhānesu cittassa parisuddha ttā upari kilesānaṃ appahīna ttā
translated: Because the mind is purified in three cases, and because the defilements in the higher stages have not been abandoned.

original: Yathā, mahārāja, vaṁsanāḷassa tipabbagaṇṭhiparisuddhassa upari sākhājaṭājaṭitassa ākaḍḍhiyantassa yāva tipabbaṁ tāva lahukaṁ eti, tato upari thaddhaṁ.
analyzed: yathā mahā rāja vasanāḷassa ti pabba gaṇṭhi parisuddhassa upari sākhā jaṭā jaṭitassa ākaḍḍhiyantassa yāva ti pabbam tāva lahukam eti tatas upari thaddha
translated: It is just as, your Majesty, when a bamboo has three joints that are cleared of knots, and above that it is entangled with a tangle of branches and twigs, and when it is pulled, it moves easily as far as the three joints, and above that it is stiff.

original: Kiṁ kāraṇā?
analyzed: kim kāraṇā
translated: Why is that?

original: Heṭṭhā parisuddhattā upari sākhājaṭājaṭitattā.
analyzed: heṭṭhā parisuddha ttā upari sākhā jaṭā jaṭita ttā
translated: Because below it is cleared, and above it is entangled with a tangle of branches and twigs.

original: Evameva kho, mahārāja, ye te sotāpannā pihitāpāyā diṭṭhippattā viññātasatthusāsanā,🔽tesaṁ taṁ cittaṁ tīsu ṭhānesu lahukaṁ uppajjati lahukaṁ pavattati, uparibhūmīsu garukaṁ
analyzed: evam eva kho mahā rāja ye te sotāpannāḥ pihita apāyāḥ diṭṭhi ppattāḥ viññāta satthu sāsanāḥ  tesam tam cittam tīsu ṭhānesu lahukam uppajjati lahukam pavattati upari bhūmīsu garuka
translated: In the same way, your Majesty, the minds of those stream-enterers who have closed off the lower realms, who have attained the view, who have understood the Teacher’s message,

translated: arise and occur lightly in three cases, and in the higher stages they arise and occur heavily.🔽Why is that?

original: Kiṁ kāraṇā?
analyzed: kim kāraṇā

analyzed: tīsu ṭhānesu cittassa parisuddha ttā upari kilesānaṃ appahīna ttā idam dutiyam citta
translated: Because of the purity of mind in three places and because of the non-abandoning of the higher defilements, this is the second kind of mind.

analyzed: tatra idam tatiyam cittam vibhattam āpajjati
translated: Herein, this third kind of mind is analyzed thus:

original: Kiṁ kāraṇā?

analyzed: garukam uppajjati dandham pavattati
translated: it arises slowly and proceeds slowly.

analyzed: kim kāraṇā

original: Kiṁ kāraṇā?
analyzed: kim kāraṇā
translated: Why is that?

analyzed: sabba pabba gaṇṭhi parisuddha ttā a gahana ttā vasassa

analyzed: evam eva kho mahā rāja ye te arahantaḥ khīṇa āsavāḥ dhota malāḥ vanta kilesāḥ vusitavantaḥ
translated: Even so, sire, the minds of those arahats who are rid of the corruptions, who have washed off the stain, who have ended the defilements, who have lived the life,

analyzed: saka visaye parisuddha vimala cittā tesam tam cittam saka visaye lahukam uppajjati
translated: whose minds are purified in their own field, for them that consciousness arises and occurs lightly in their own field,

translated: Why is that?

translated: Because of the purity of their own field and the vastness of the plane of the omniscient Buddhas.

translated: As, great king, a man might cross a small river in his own province at any time he likes, without fear or hesitation,

original: dandhāyeyya na visaheyya otarituṁ.
analyzed: dandhāyeyya na visaheyya otaritu
translated: but when he saw the great ocean, deep and wide, unfathomable and shoreless, he would be afraid and would hesitate and would not dare to enter it.

original: Kiṁ kāraṇā?
analyzed: kim kāraṇā
translated: Why is that?

original: Tiṇṇattā sakavisayassa, mahantattā ca mahāsamuddassa.
analyzed: tiṇṇattā saka visayassa mahantattā ca mahā samuddassa
translated: Because he has crossed his own province and because of the vastness of the great ocean.

original: Evameva kho, mahārāja, ye te paccekabuddhā sayambhuno anācariyakā ekacārino khaggavisāṇakappā🔽sakavisaye parisuddhavimalacittā, tesaṁ taṁ cittaṁ sakavisaye lahukaṁ uppajjati lahukaṁ
analyzed: evam eva kho mahā rāja ye te paccekabuddhā sayambhunaḥ an ācariyakāḥ eka cārinaḥ khagga visāṇa kappā  saka visaye parisuddha vimala cittā tesam tam cittam saka visaye lahukam uppajjati
translated: Even so, sire, the minds of those Paccekabuddhas who are self-dependent, who have no teacher, who go alone like the horn of the rhinoceros,

original: pavattati, sabbaññubuddhabhūmīsu garukaṁ uppajjati dandhaṁ pavattati.
analyzed: pavattati sabbaññu buddha bhūmīsu garukam uppajjati dandham pavattati
translated: whose minds are pure and clear in their own sphere, arise quickly and move quickly in their own sphere, but they arise slowly and move slowly in the sphere of the all-knowing Buddhas.

original: Kiṁ kāraṇā?
analyzed: kim kāraṇā
translated: Why is this?

original: Parisuddhattā sakavisaye mahantattā sabbaññubuddhavisayassa, idaṁ chaṭṭhaṁ cittaṁ.
analyzed: parisuddha ttā saka visaye mahanta ttā sabbaññu buddha visayassa idam chaṭṭham citta
translated: Because of the purity in their own sphere and the greatness of the sphere of the all-knowing Buddhas. This is the sixth kind of mind.

original: Tatridaṁ sattamaṁ cittaṁ vibhattamāpajjati—🔽ye te, mahārāja, sammāsambuddhā sabbaññuno dasabaladharā catuvesārajjavisāradā aṭṭhārasahi🔽buddhadhammehi samannāgatā anantajinā anāvaraṇañāṇā, tesaṁ taṁ cittaṁ sabbattha lahukaṁ
analyzed: tatra idam sattamam cittam vibhattam āpajjati  ye te mahā rāja sammāsambuddhā sabbaññunaḥ dasa bala dharā catu vesārajja visāradā aṭṭhārasa hi  buddha dhammehi samannāgatā ananta jināḥ anāvaraṇa ñāṇā tesam tam cittam sabbattha lahuka
translated: Herein, sire, the seventh kind of mind is distinguished thus—

original: uppajjati lahukaṁ pavattati.
analyzed: uppajjati lahukam pavattati
translated: the minds of those Fully Enlightened Ones who are all-knowing, who bear the ten powers, who are confident with the four confidences, who are endowed with the eighteen qualities of the Buddhas, who are infinite victors, who have unobstructed knowledge, arise quickly and move quickly everywhere.

original: Kiṁ kāraṇā?
analyzed: kim kāraṇā
translated: Why is this?

original: Sabbattha parisuddhattā.
analyzed: sabbattha parisuddhattā
translated: Because of the purity everywhere.

original: Api nu kho, mahārāja, nārācassa sudhotassa vimalassa niggaṇṭhissa sukhumadhārassa🔽ajimhassa avaṅkassa akuṭilassa daḷhacāpasamārūḷhassa khomasukhume vā kappāsasukhume
analyzed: api nu kho mahā rāja nārācassa sudhotassa vimalassa niggaṇṭhissa sukhumadhārassa  a jimhassa a vaṅkassa a kuṭilassa daḷha cāpa samārūḍhassa khoma sukhume vā kappāsa sukhume
translated: when it is well-polished, clean, without a notch, with a fine shaft,

original: vā kambalasukhume vā balavanipātitassa dandhāyitattaṁ vā lagganaṁ vā hotī”ti?
analyzed: vā kambala sukhume vā balava nipātitassa dandhāyi tattam vā lagganam vā hoti iti
translated: not crooked, not twisted, well-fitted to the bow, and shot with great force, whether it be into cotton-down, or silk floss, or wool?”

original: “Na hi, bhante”.
analyzed: na hi bhante
translated: “No, revered sir.”

original: “Kiṁ kāraṇā?
analyzed: kim kāraṇā
translated: “Why is that?

original: Sukhumattā vatthānaṁ sudhotattā nārācassa nipātassa ca balavattāti;
analyzed: sukhuma ttā vatthānam sudhota ttā nārācassa nipātassa ca balava ttā ati
translated: Because of the fineness of the cloth, the well-polishedness of the arrow, and the great force of the shot;

original: evameva kho, mahārāja, ye te sammāsambuddhā sabbaññuno dasabaladharā catuvesārajjavisāradā
analyzed: evam eva kho mahā rāja ye te sammāsambuddhā sabbaññunaḥ dasa bala dharā catu vesārajja visāradā
translated: even so, sire, the minds of those who are fully enlightened, all-knowing, possessors of the ten powers, confident in the fourfold confidence,

original: aṭṭhārasahi buddhadhammehi samannāgatā anantajinā anāvaraṇañāṇā, tesaṁ taṁ cittaṁ
analyzed: aṭṭhārasahi buddha dhammehi samannāgatā ananta jināḥ anāvaraṇa ñāṇā tesam tam citta
translated: endowed with the eighteen qualities of the Buddha, infinite victors, whose knowledge is unobstructed,

original: sabbattha lahukaṁ uppajjati lahukaṁ pavattati.
analyzed: sabbattha lahukam uppajjati lahukam pavattati
translated: arise quickly and proceed quickly everywhere.

original: Kiṁ kāraṇā?
analyzed: kim kāraṇā
translated: Why is that?

original: Sabbattha parisuddhattā, idaṁ sattamaṁ cittaṁ.
analyzed: sabbattha idam sattamam
translated: Because of the purity everywhere; this is the seventh mind.

original: Tatra, mahārāja, yadidaṁ sabbaññubuddhānaṁ cittaṁ, taṁ channampi cittānaṁ gaṇanaṁ atikkamitvā asaṅkhyeyyena guṇena parisuddhañca lahukañca.
analyzed: tatra mahā rāja yat idam sabbaññu buddhānam citta tam channam pi cittānam gaṇanam atikkamitvā asaṅkhyeyyena guṇena parisuddham ca lahukam ca
translated: Herein, sire, the mind of the all-knowing Buddhas, surpassing the reckoning of the six kinds of mind, is purified and light by reason of its incalculable virtue.

original: Yasmā ca bhagavato cittaṁ parisuddhañca lahukañca, tasmā, mahārāja, bhagavā yamakapāṭihīraṁ dasseti.🔽Yamakapāṭihīre, mahārāja, ñātabbaṁ buddhānaṁ bhagavantānaṁ cittaṁ evaṁ lahuparivattanti,🔽na tattha sakkā uttariṁ kāraṇaṁ vattuṁ, tepi, mahārāja, pāṭihīrā sabbaññubuddhānaṁ
analyzed: yasmā ca bhagavato cittam parisuddham ca lahukam ca tasmai mahā rāja bhagavā yamaka pāṭihīram dasseti  yamaka pāṭihīre mahā rāja ñātabbam buddhānam bhagavantānam cittam evam lahu parivattanti  na tattha sakkā uttarim kāraṇam vattu te pi mahā rāja pāṭihīrā sabbaññu buddhāna
translated: And because the mind of the Exalted One is purified and light, therefore, sire, the Exalted One shows the twin miracle.🔽In the twin miracle, sire, it should be known that the mind of the Buddhas, the Exalted Ones, is so light in its operation.

original: cittaṁ upādāya gaṇanampi saṅkhampi kalampi kalabhāgampi na upenti, āvajjanapaṭibaddhaṁ,
analyzed: cittam upādāya gaṇanam pi saṅkham pi kalam pi kala bhāgam pi na upenti āvajjana paṭibaddha
translated: Herein, sire, there is no further reason to be stated. These miracles, too, sire, in comparison with the mind of the all-knowing Buddhas, do not count, are not reckoned, are not a fraction, are not a moiety. They are bound up with the act of attention.

original: mahārāja, bhagavato sabbaññutañāṇaṁ, āvajjetvā yadicchakaṁ jānāti.🔽Yathā, mahārāja, puriso hatthe ṭhapitaṁ yaṁ kiñci dutiye hatthe ṭhapeyya vivaṭena
analyzed: mahā rāja bhagavataḥ sabbaññuta ñāṇe āvajjetvā yadicchakam jānāti 🔽yathā mahā rāja purisaḥ hatthe ṭhapitam yam kiñci dutiye hatthe ṭhapeyya vivaṭena
translated: The all-knowing knowledge of the Exalted One, sire, is bound up with the act of attention. Having attended to it, he knows what he wishes.

original: mukhena vācaṁ nicchāreyya, mukhagataṁ bhojanaṁ gileyya, ummīletvā vā nimīleyya, nimīletvā
analyzed: mukhena vācam nicchāreyya mukha gatam bhojanam gileyya ummīletvā vā nimīleyya nimīletvā
translated: he should not speak with his mouth full; he should not eat with his mouth wide open; he should not open his eyes wide and then close them;

original: vā ummīleyya, samiñjitaṁ vā bāhaṁ pasāreyya, pasāritaṁ vā bāhaṁ samiñjeyya, cirataraṁ
analyzed: vā ummīleyya samiñjitam vā bāham pasāreyya pasāritam vā bāham samiñjeyya ciratara
translated: he could open his mouth, he could swallow food, he could open his eyes after closing them, he could close his eyes after opening them, he could stretch out his arm after bending it, he could bend his arm after stretching it out.

original: etaṁ, mahārāja, lahutaraṁ bhagavato sabbaññutañāṇaṁ, lahutaraṁ āvajjanaṁ, āvajjetvā
analyzed: eta mahā rāja lahutaram bhagavataḥ sabbaññuta ñāṇa lahutaram āvajjane āvajjetvā
translated: “Your Majesty, the knowledge of the Omniscient One is more rapid than that, more rapid is his adverting, after adverting he knows whatever he wishes.

original: yadicchakaṁ jānāti, āvajjanavikalamattakena na tāvatā buddhā bhagavanto asabbaññuno nāma hontī”ti.
analyzed: yadicchakam jānāti āvajjana vikala mattakena na tāvatā buddhāḥ bhagavantaḥ asabbaññunaḥ nāma honti iti
translated: He is not called a Buddha, a Blessed One, because of the mere incompleteness of his adverting.”

original: “Āvajjanampi, bhante nāgasena, pariyesanāya kātabbaṁ, iṅgha maṁ tattha kāraṇena saññāpehī”ti.
analyzed: āvajjanam pi bhante nāgasena pariyesanāya kātabbaḥ iṅgha mama tattha kāraṇena saññāpehi iti
translated: “Revered Nāgasena, adverting too must be sought for, now convince me by a reason as to that.”

original: “Yathā, mahārāja, purisassa aḍḍhassa mahaddhanassa mahābhogassa pahūtajātarūparajatassa
analyzed: yathā mahā rāja purisassa aḍḍhassa mahat dhanassa mahā bhogassa pahūta jātarūpa rajatassa
translated: “As, sire, a man might be rich, of great wealth, of great possessions, of great riches,

original: pahūtavittūpakaraṇassa pahūtadhanadhaññassa sālivīhiyavataṇḍulatilamuggamāsapubbaṇṇāparaṇṇasappitelanavanītakhīradadhimadhuguḷaphāṇitā
analyzed: pahūta vittu upakaraṇassa pahūta dhana dhaññassa sāli vīhi yava taṇḍula tila mugga māsa pubbaṇṇa aparaṇṇa sappi tela navanīta khīra dadhi madhu guḷa phāṇi tā
translated: of great property, of great means, of great store of gold and silver, of great store of jewels, of great store of wealth and corn, of great store of rice, barley, beans, millet, kodo millet, chickpeas, sesame, green gram, and other kinds of pulse, of great store of oil, ghee, butter, milk, curd, honey, sugar,

original: ca khaḷopikumbhipīṭharakoṭṭhabhājanagatā bhaveyyuṁ, tassa ca purisassa pāhunako āgaccheyya
analyzed: ca khaḷopi kumbhi pīṭhara koṭṭha bhājana gatāḥ bhaveyyu tassa ca purisassa pāhunakaḥ āgaccheyya
translated: and they were in a pot, a jar, a tub, or a basket, and a guest should come to that man

original: bhattāraho bhattābhikaṅkhī, tassa ca gehe yaṁ randhaṁ bhojanaṁ, taṁ pariniṭṭhitaṁ
analyzed: bhattā rahaḥ bhatta abhikaṅkhī tassa ca gehe yam randham bhojana tam
translated: who deserved food and was in need of food, and all the food that was to be cooked in the house should be finished,

original: bhaveyya, kumbhito taṇḍule nīharitvā bhojanaṁ randheyya, api ca kho so, mahārāja,
analyzed: bhaveyya taṇḍule nīharitvā bhojanam randheyya api ca kho saḥ mahā rāja
translated: he would take rice from the pot and cook food. But, great king,

original: tāvatakena bhojanavekallamattakena adhano nāma kapaṇo nāma bhaveyyā”ti?
analyzed: tāvatakena bhojana vekallamattakena adhanaḥ nāma kapaṇaḥ nāma bhaveyyāti
translated: would he be called poor and destitute because of that small lack of food?”

original: “Na hi, bhante, cakkavattirañño gharepi, bhante, akāle bhojanavekallaṁ hoti, kiṁ pana gahapatikassā”ti?
analyzed: na hi bhante cakkavatti raññaḥ ghare pi bhante akāle bhojana vekallam hoti kim pana gahapatikassa ati
translated: “No, venerable sir. Even in the house of a universal monarch, venerable sir, there is no lack of food at any time, so how much less so in the house of a householder.”

original: “Evameva kho, mahārāja, tathāgatassa āvajjanavikalamattakaṁ sabbaññutañāṇaṁ āvajjetvā yadicchakaṁ jānāti.
analyzed: evam eva kho mahā rāja tathāgatassa āvajjana vikala mattakam sabbaññuta ñāṇam āvajjetvā yadicchakam jānāti
translated: “So too, great king, the Tathāgata’s knowledge of omniscience is unimpaired. Having known with his knowledge of omniscience whatever he wishes to know,

original: Yathā vā pana, mahārāja, rukkho assa phalito oṇatavinato piṇḍibhārabharito, na kiñci
analyzed: yathā vā pana mahā rāja rukkhaḥ assa phalitaḥ piṇḍi bhāra bharitaḥ na kiñci
translated: Just as, great king, a tree might be laden with fruit, bent down, almost breaking with the clusters of fruit, and yet

original: tattha patitaṁ phalaṁ bhaveyya, api nu kho so, mahārāja, rukkho tāvatakena patitaphalavekallamattakena
analyzed: tattha patitam phalam bhaveyya api nu kho saḥ mahā rāja rukkho tāvatakena patita phala vekalla mattakena
translated: If a fruit fell from that tree, would that tree🔽be deprived of fruit because of the loss of that one fruit?

original: aphalo nāma bhaveyyā”ti?
analyzed: aphalaḥ nāma bhaveyyāti
translated: If a fruit fell from the tree, would that tree then be called fruitless because of the loss of that one fruit?”

original: “Na hi, bhante, patanapaṭibaddhāni tāni rukkhaphalāni, patite yadicchakaṁ labhatī”ti.
analyzed: na hi bhante patana paṭibaddhāni tāni rukkha phalāni patite yadicchakam labhati iti
translated: “No, revered sir, those fruits of the tree are not bound to it by a string, one can get them when one wants.”

original: “Evameva kho, mahārāja, tathāgatassa āvajjanapaṭibaddhaṁ sabbaññutañāṇaṁ āvajjetvā yadicchakaṁ jānātī”ti.
analyzed: evam eva kho mahā rāja tathāgatassa āvajjana paṭibaddham sabbaññuta ñāṇam āvajjetvā yadicchakam jānāti iti
translated: “Even so, sire, the Tathāgata’s knowledge of omniscience is bound to his adverting; he knows what he wants when he adverts.”

original: “Bhante nāgasena, āvajjetvā āvajjetvā buddho yadicchakaṁ jānātī”ti?
analyzed: bhante nāgasena āvajjetvā āvajjetvā buddhaḥ yadicchakam jānāti iti
translated: “Revered Nāgasena, does the Buddha know what he wants by adverting again and again?”

original: “Āma, mahārāja, bhagavā āvajjetvā āvajjetvā yadicchakaṁ jānātīti.🔽Yathā, mahārāja, cakkavattī rājā yadā cakkaratanaṁ sarati ‘upetu me cakkaratanan’ti, sarite cakkaratanaṁ upeti;
analyzed: āma mahā rāja bhagavān āvajjetvā āvajjetvā yadicchakam jānāti iti  yathā mahā rāja cakkavattī rājā yadā cakka ratanam sarati upetu me sarite cakka ratanam upeti
translated: “Yes, sire, the Blessed One knows what he wants by adverting again and again.

original: evameva kho, mahārāja, tathāgato āvajjetvā āvajjetvā yadicchakaṁ jānātī”ti.
analyzed: evam eva khalu mahā rāja tathāgataḥ āvajjetvā āvajjetvā yadicchakam jānāti iti
translated: As, sire, when a universal monarch wants to test the precious gem he has, he says: ‘Come, let the precious gem be brought,’ and when the precious gem has been brought he says: ‘Come, weigh the precious gem,’ and when the precious gem has been weighed he says: ‘Come, test the precious gem,’ and when the precious gem has been tested he says: ‘Come, put the precious gem away,’ and when the precious gem has been put away he does not need to test it again, so too, sire, the Tathāgata knows what he wants by adverting again and again.”

original: “Daḷhaṁ, bhante nāgasena, kāraṇaṁ, buddho sabbaññū, sampaṭicchāma buddho sabbaññū”ti.
analyzed: daḷha bhante nāgasena kāraṇa buddhaḥ sabbaññū sampaṭicchāma buddhaḥ sabbaññū ti
translated: “The reason is strong, revered Nāgasena; the Buddha was omniscient; we accept that the Buddha was omniscient.”

original: Buddhasabbaññubhāvapañho dutiyo.
analyzed: buddha sabbaññu bhāva pañhaḥ dutiyaḥ
translated: Question on the Omniscience of the Buddha, second.
